G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3.proposition: The amount in controversy exceeds $50,000, exclusive of interest and costs, thereby placing this matter within the subject-matter jurisdiction of the Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 3.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2..proposition: Venue is proper in Berkshire County because the events giving rise to this action occurred in Pittsfield, Berkshire County, Massachusetts, and the Defendant resides in Berkshire County.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner or person in control of property owes a duty to all lawful visitors to act as a reasonable person under all the circumstances, including with respect to the maintenance of trees and overhanging branches, and to take reasonable steps to prevent foreseeable harm.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 6B, 6C.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover fair and reasonable compensatory damages from Defendant, including but not limited to: past and future medical expenses, past and future lost earnings and/or loss of earning capacity, pain and suffering, emotional distress, and loss of enjoyment of life, together with interest and costs, pursuant to G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B, 6C.

*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner or person in control of property owes a duty to all lawful visitors to act as a reasonable person under all the circumstances, including with respect to the maintenance of trees and overhanging branches, and to take reasonable steps to prevent foreseeable harm.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard abolished the common-law distinction between invitees and licensees in Massachusetts and held that an occupier owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. That general principle logically includes conditions on the premises such as trees and overhanging branches, even though the opinion does not specifically discuss trees. The concurrence excerpt criticizes continued categorization of trespassers, reinforcing the shift toward a unified reasonable-care standard for lawful entrants, but the tree-specific aspect of the proposition is an application rather than something directly addressed in the text provided.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.relevant_excerpt: The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a “licensee” rather than an “invitee,” or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. … The very effort at dry classification and differentiation puts the emphasis at the wrong places.

*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner or person in control of property owes a duty to all lawful visitors to act as a reasonable person under all the circumstances, including with respect to the maintenance of trees and overhanging branches, and to take reasonable steps to prevent foreseeable harm.
*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.support_reasoning: The court expressly states the modern Massachusetts rule that an owner or possessor of land owes a common‑law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors, including maintaining the premises in reasonably safe condition. While the case ultimately holds that this duty does not extend to altering an adjacent state highway, it clearly affirms the general duty standard the proposition relies on. Trees and branches are not discussed specifically, but they fall within the broader “maintenance of the premises” obligation the court describes.
*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.relevant_excerpt: “It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825, 827 (1994), citing Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973). This duty includes an obligation to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition and to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware.”

*Sweeney v. Old Colony & Newport R.R. Co.raw_text: *Sweeney v. Old Colony & Newport R.R. Co.*, 10 Allen 368 (Mass. 1865)
*Sweeney v. Old Colony & Newport R.R. Co.proposition: A landowner’s duty of reasonable care extends to persons lawfully traveling upon adjacent public ways who may be foreseeably injured by dangerous conditions on the land, including defective trees and branches overhanging public sidewalks.

*Laflamme v. Dallessio*, 261 Mass. 504 (.proposition: A landowner’s duty of reasonable care extends to persons lawfully traveling upon adjacent public ways who may be foreseeably injured by dangerous conditions on the land, including defective trees and branches overhanging public sidewalks.
*Laflamme v. Dallessio*, 261 Mass. 504 (.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns forfeiture of a motor vehicle used to transport intoxicating liquor and due process limits on confiscation of property. It does not discuss premises liability, landowner duties, conditions of land abutting public ways, or defective trees/branches overhanging sidewalks. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the asserted rule about a landowner’s duty to travelers on adjacent public ways.
*Laflamme v. Dallessio*, 261 Mass. 504 (.relevant_excerpt: "This is a proceeding for the forfeiture of a motor vehicle seized as a vessel containing intoxicating liquor or an implement 'of sale actually used in transporting' certain intoxicating liquors 'contrary to law.'... The proceeding is primarily a process in rem to procure the condemnation and forfeiture of property illegally used. It is criminal in its nature..."

*Mahoney v. Perreault*, 275 Mass. 251 (1.proposition: Massachusetts cases recognize that when a landowner has actual or constructive notice of a defective or decayed tree or limb that threatens persons using a nearby public way, the landowner has a duty to exercise reasonable care to inspect, maintain, and, where appropriate, remove or remediate the hazard.
*Mahoney v. Perreault*, 275 Mass. 251 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion deals exclusively with a landowner’s duties regarding snow and ice on a sidewalk abutting his property, and holds that an abutting owner has no duty to keep the way clear of snow or ice from natural causes. It does not discuss trees, defective or decayed limbs, or any duty to inspect, maintain, or remove hazardous trees adjacent to a public way. Accordingly, it provides no authority for the tree-related duty described in the proposition.
*Mahoney v. Perreault*, 275 Mass. 251 (1.relevant_excerpt: "This court has repeatedly held that the owner of premises abutting upon a public way has no duty to keep the way clear from snow, ice or water which is upon it from natural causes, or to guard against accident by placing sawdust or other substances upon the sidewalk."

*Jones v. Hayden*, 310 Mass. 90 (1941).proposition: Massachusetts cases recognize that when a landowner has actual or constructive notice of a defective or decayed tree or limb that threatens persons using a nearby public way, the landowner has a duty to exercise reasonable care to inspect, maintain, and, where appropriate, remove or remediate the hazard.
*Jones v. Hayden*, 310 Mass. 90 (1941).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns obstruction of a sidewalk by hay bales and a parked truck, creating an alleged public nuisance that forced the plaintiff into a dangerous, icy roadway. It does not involve trees, decayed limbs, vegetative conditions, or a landowner’s duty to inspect or remove hazardous trees adjacent to a public way. The holding and reasoning focus on nuisance via unreasonable obstruction and proximate cause, so the case does not establish or discuss the tree-related duty described in the proposition.
*Jones v. Hayden*, 310 Mass. 90 (1941).relevant_excerpt: “It is settled that one ‘does not create a nuisance who obstructs a way if . . . the obstruction is not for an unreasonable length of time, is reasonably necessary for the transaction of business and does not unreasonably interfere with the rights of the public.’ … In the present case the jury could have found that the roadway was dangerous to travel, that the sidewalk was completely blocked for an unreasonable time… and that the plaintiff was obliged to go into the roadway in order to pass the obstruction.”

*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.proposition: Further, a landowner who has actual knowledge of a specific hazardous condition—such as a visibly cracked, drooping tree limb over a sidewalk—owes a duty to take reasonable measures to correct the condition or to warn foreseeable users of the danger.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.support_reasoning: Papadopoulos concerns premises liability for snow and ice and abolishes the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction, but it does not address trees, tree limbs, or a special rule about a landowner’s “actual knowledge of a specific hazardous condition” such as a visibly cracked, drooping tree limb. The opinion does restate the general duty of reasonable care to lawful visitors when the owner knows or should know of a dangerous condition, but it is not authority for the specific, tree-limb-focused proposition stated. The citation is therefore too specific for what the case actually holds.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property, whether arising from an accumulation of snow or ice, or rust on a railing, or a discarded banana peel, the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.” Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368, 383 (2010).

*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148 (2.proposition: Further, a landowner who has actual knowledge of a specific hazardous condition—such as a visibly cracked, drooping tree limb over a sidewalk—owes a duty to take reasonable measures to correct the condition or to warn foreseeable users of the danger.
*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148 (2.support_reasoning: The case does address a landowner’s duty regarding known hazards, but it does so in the specific context of the “open and obvious danger” doctrine and the duty to remedy such dangers. The opinion repeatedly emphasizes that, under Massachusetts law, a landowner is relieved of the duty to warn of open and obvious dangers; the residual duty is to remedy or correct the condition where the owner can and should anticipate harm, not an additional independent duty to warn. Thus, while the case supports a duty to take reasonable corrective measures when the owner knows of a dangerous condition that entrants will likely encounter, it does not support a continuing duty to warn about an open and obvious hazard such as the example given in the proposition.
*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148 (2.relevant_excerpt: “However, ‘[l]andowners are relieved of the duty to warn of open and obvious dangers on their premises because it is not reasonably foreseeable that a visitor…would suffer injury from such blatant hazards.’ … A landowner, though, ‘is not relieved from remedying an open and obvious danger where [the landowner] “can and should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm to the [lawful visitor] notwithstanding its known or obvious danger.”’ … [T]he existence of an open and obvious danger will not necessarily relieve a landowner of the duty to remedy that danger.”

*Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth.*, 92.raw_text: *Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth.*, 92 Mass. App. Ct. 129, 133–134 (2017)
*Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth.*, 92.proposition: Defendant’s inaction in the face of known danger constituted a failure to maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition and a breach of his duty of reasonable care owed to Plaintiff and others using the adjacent public sidewalk.

*Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 905 F.2.raw_text: *Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 905 F.2d 515, 524 (1st Cir. 1990)
*Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 905 F.2.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was a substantial contributing factor in causing Plaintiff’s injuries and resulting losses.
*Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 905 F.2.case_name: Lisa Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Authority, Appeal of Donald Hertzfeldt and Peter Langley
*Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 905 F.2.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses proximate cause standards, including that a defendant’s negligence must be a substantial factor, but it ultimately holds that plaintiffs failed to prove Massport’s negligence was a substantial factor in causing their alleged reputation-based losses. Thus, rather than affirmatively finding that the defendant’s negligence was a substantial contributing factor to plaintiffs’ injuries and losses, the court concludes the opposite for these claimed damages. The case states the rule but does not support the proposition as an applied, favorable finding for the plaintiff on this point.
*Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 905 F.2.relevant_excerpt: “Under Massachusetts law, proximate cause requires a showing by the plaintiff, first, that the loss was a foreseeable consequence of the defendant's negligence, second, that the defendant's negligence was a but-for cause of the loss, and third, that the defendant's negligence was a substantial factor in bringing about the loss.… The district court overturned the jury's verdict on the ground that the evidence presented in the case ‘was insufficient to support a reasoned finding by the jury that the losses alleged by plaintiffs through harm to reputation were proximately caused by the negligence of Massport.’”

*Hill v. Winsor*, 118 Mass. 251, 259 (18.proposition: The ordinary summer thunderstorm on August 15, 2023, was not an extraordinary or unforeseeable event, but rather a normal weather occurrence in Massachusetts that a reasonable property owner must anticipate when assessing the safety of trees and branches.
*Hill v. Winsor*, 118 Mass. 251, 259 (18.support_reasoning: The opinion does not address weather, storms, or foreseeability of natural events. It concerns negligence in managing a tug-boat and clarifies that a defendant cannot escape liability merely by following usual practices if danger was foreseeable. It therefore cannot be used as authority for the proposition about an ordinary summer thunderstorm being a foreseeable event for property owners assessing tree safety.
*Hill v. Winsor*, 118 Mass. 251, 259 (18.relevant_excerpt: As to the second and sixth, it is enough to say that there is no rule of law which exempts one from the consequences of his negligent conduct upon proof that he proceeded in the usual manner and took the usual course pursued by parties similarly situated, although he was without notice that he could not safely do so. The defendants cannot protect themselves by proving the careless practices of others, and the circumstances here were such as to justify the inference that the defendants were bound to take notice of the danger.

*Jones v. Wayland*, 374 Mass. 249 (1978).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a tortfeasor is liable for all damages proximately caused by his negligence, including medical expenses, lost wages, and pain and suffering.
*Jones v. Wayland*, 374 Mass. 249 (1978).support_reasoning: The case is not a tort action and does not discuss the scope of a tortfeasor’s liability or categories of tort damages. It addresses statutory wage‑replacement benefits for injured police officers under G.L. c. 41, § 111F, and the effect of resignation and insurance payments on those benefits. Although it mentions the collateral source rule in passing, it does not hold that a tortfeasor is liable for all damages proximately caused by negligence, including medical expenses, lost wages, and pain and suffering.
*Jones v. Wayland*, 374 Mass. 249 (1978).relevant_excerpt: “As a general rule, a tortfeasor’s liability to an injured person shall not be reduced by the amount of compensation received by the injured person pursuant to an insurance policy. Commonly referred to as the ‘collateral source rule,’ the doctrine requires that ‘the damages . . . must be paid by one who has caused the insured’s disability.’ Shea v. Rettie, 287 Mass. 454, 458 (1934). … Where, as here, the party found liable is not responsible for the injury, the rule would appear to be inapplicable.”
